title: 110_s1235
content: The Act titled the "Daniel Faulkner Law Enforcement Officers and Judges Protection Act of 2007" includes special penalties for the murder or kidnapping of a federal law enforcement officer or federal judge. The "Daniel Faulkner Law Enforcement Officers and Judges Protection Act of 2007" amends Section 1114 of title 18, United States Code to impose harsh penalties for the murder of a Federal law enforcement officer or a United States judge. Offenders face death or life imprisonment for first-degree murder, imprisonment for at least 25 years for second-degree murder, and at least 10 years for voluntary manslaughter. The amendment to Section 1201(a) of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for kidnapping offenses involving Federal law enforcement officers or United States judges. Offenders face a fine, imprisonment for at least 20 years, or life imprisonment, with the possibility of the death penalty if death results. Special penalties are imposed for assaulting a federal law enforcement officer or federal judge, with potential imprisonment for at least 20 years or life, and the death penalty if death occurs. Section 111 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit assaulting or interfering with certain officers or employees engaged in official duties. Penalties include imprisonment for at least 20 years or life, and the death penalty if death occurs. Any person who violates the prohibition on assaulting or interfering with certain officers or employees engaged in official duties may face fines, imprisonment for up to 20 years, or up to life imprisonment if death occurs. If the victim of an assault punishable under this section is a Federal law enforcement officer or a United States judge and the assault resulted in substantial bodily injury, the offender shall be fined and imprisoned for not less than 5 years nor more than 30 years. The offender shall be punished with a fine and imprisonment for not less than 10 years or for life if the assault resulted in serious bodily injury or a dangerous weapon was used. This punishment is in addition to any other punishment for criminal conduct during the same episode. SEC. 4 imposes special penalties for retaliating against a federal law enforcement officer or federal judge by murdering or assaulting a family member. Section 115 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for offenses committed with the intent to impede, intimidate, or interfere with a Federal law enforcement officer or a United States judge. This includes murder, attempted murder, or conspiracy. The amended Section 115 of title 18, United States Code, includes penalties for various offenses committed against Federal law enforcement officers or United States judges, such as murder, attempted murder, conspiracy, kidnapping, assault with bodily injury, and threats. Penalties include fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years, in addition to any other punishment for criminal conduct during the same episode. Section 2237(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by removing "in section 115(c)" and replacing it with "in section 115". Federal judges and federal prosecutors are authorized to carry firearms. Federal judges, prosecutors, and Department of Justice employees involved in legal representation are allowed to carry firearms under the Daniel Faulkner Law Enforcement Officers and Judges Protection Act of 2007. The Attorney General must establish regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General must establish regulations for training and certification in firearm use for federal judges, justices, and other legal officials. The effective date for these regulations will be 90 days after promulgation. A technical amendment will be made to the table of sections in title 18 of the United States Code. Federal judges and prosecutors, as well as law enforcement officers of the Amtrak Police Department and federal agencies, are authorized to carry firearms under amendments to Title 18 of the United States Code. Retired law enforcement officers are also included in these provisions. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow law enforcement officers who have served for at least 10 years to meet firearms training standards annually. Title 18, United States Code is amended to allow law enforcement officers with at least 10 years of service to meet annual firearms training standards. This includes redesignating paragraphs and updating qualifications for carrying concealed firearms. The amendment allows law enforcement officers with 10 years of service to meet firearms training standards set by the State or a certified firearms instructor. This includes qualifying to carry a concealed firearm based on active duty standards or standards set by a law enforcement agency within the State. The amendment expands the definition of 'service with a public agency as a law enforcement officer' to include officers of the Amtrak Police Department and federal law enforcement agencies. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON DAMAGES DURING COMMISSION OF A FELONY OR CRIME OF VIOLENCE. Section 1979 of the Revised States (42 U.S.C. 1983) is amended to limit injunctive relief in actions against judicial officers and restrict relief for deprivations related to felonies or crimes of violence. The text amends Section 722(b) of the Revised Statutes (42 U.S.C. 1988(b)) regarding attorney's fees in actions against judicial officers, limiting liability for costs and attorneys fees unless the action was clearly in excess of the officer's jurisdiction. The text limits liability for attorney's fees in actions related to conduct constituting a felony or crime of violence, unless the action was clearly in excess of the officer's jurisdiction. SEC. 7. FEDERAL REVIEW OF STATE CONVICTION FOR MURDER OF A LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER OR JUDGE. Section 2254 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for habeas corpus applications on behalf of individuals convicted of killing a public safety officer or judge. The application must adhere to specific time limitations and requirements, and the court cannot consider claims related to sentencing already adjudicated in a State court. The amendments to Section 2254 of title 28, United States Code, provide provisions for habeas corpus applications for individuals convicted of killing public safety officers or judges. Federal courts are limited to staying death sentences imposed by State courts, and specific rules and limitations apply to these cases. The amendments made by this section apply to cases pending on or after the enactment date of the Act. Time limits for actions in pending cases will start from the enactment date. An exception allows consideration of amendments to habeas corpus applications pending before the enactment date if already adjudicated by the court.
